speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: If music be the food of love, play on;

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: Give me excess of it, that, surfeiting,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: The appetite may sicken, and so die.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: That strain again! it had a dying fall:

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: O, it came o'er my ear like the sweet sound,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: That breathes upon a bank of violets,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: Stealing and giving odour! Enough; no more:

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: 'Tis not so sweet now as it was before.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: O spirit of love! how quick and fresh art thou,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: That, notwithstanding thy capacity

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: Receiveth as the sea, nought enters there,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: Of what validity and pitch soe'er,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: But falls into abatement and low price,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: Even in a minute: so full of shapes is fancy

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: That it alone is high fantastical.

speaker: CURIO
line: Will you go hunt, my lord?

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: What, Curio?

speaker: CURIO
line: The hart.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: Why, so I do, the noblest that I have:

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: O, when mine eyes did see Olivia first,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: Methought she purged the air of pestilence!

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: That instant was I turn'd into a hart;

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: And my desires, like fell and cruel hounds,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: E'er since pursue me.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: How now! what news from her?

speaker: VALENTINE
line: So please my lord, I might not be admitted;

speaker: VALENTINE
line: But from her handmaid do return this answer:

speaker: VALENTINE
line: The element itself, till seven years' heat,

speaker: VALENTINE
line: Shall not behold her face at ample view;

speaker: VALENTINE
line: But, like a cloistress, she will veiled walk

speaker: VALENTINE
line: And water once a day her chamber round

speaker: VALENTINE
line: With eye-offending brine: all this to season

speaker: VALENTINE
line: A brother's dead love, which she would keep fresh

speaker: VALENTINE
line: And lasting in her sad remembrance.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: O, she that hath a heart of that fine frame

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: To pay this debt of love but to a brother,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: How will she love, when the rich golden shaft

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: Hath kill'd the flock of all affections else

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: That live in her; when liver, brain and heart,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: These sovereign thrones, are all supplied, and fill'd

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: Her sweet perfections with one self king!

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: Away before me to sweet beds of flowers:

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: Love-thoughts lie rich when canopied with bowers.

speaker: VIOLA
line: What country, friends, is this?

speaker: Captain
line: This is Illyria, lady.

speaker: VIOLA
line: And what should I do in Illyria?

speaker: VIOLA
line: My brother he is in Elysium.

speaker: VIOLA
line: Perchance he is not drown'd: what think you, sailors?

speaker: Captain
line: It is perchance that you yourself were saved.

speaker: VIOLA
line: O my poor brother! and so perchance may he be.

speaker: Captain
line: True, madam: and, to comfort you with chance,

speaker: Captain
line: Assure yourself, after our ship did split,

speaker: Captain
line: When you and those poor number saved with you

speaker: Captain
line: Hung on our driving boat, I saw your brother,

speaker: Captain
line: Most provident in peril, bind himself,

speaker: Captain
line: Courage and hope both teaching him the practise,

speaker: Captain
line: To a strong mast that lived upon the sea;

speaker: Captain
line: Where, like Arion on the dolphin's back,

speaker: Captain
line: I saw him hold acquaintance with the waves

speaker: Captain
line: So long as I could see.

speaker: VIOLA
line: For saying so, there's gold:

speaker: VIOLA
line: Mine own escape unfoldeth to my hope,

speaker: VIOLA
line: Whereto thy speech serves for authority,

speaker: VIOLA
line: The like of him. Know'st thou this country?

speaker: Captain
line: Ay, madam, well; for I was bred and born

speaker: Captain
line: Not three hours' travel from this very place.

speaker: VIOLA
line: Who governs here?

speaker: Captain
line: A noble duke, in nature as in name.

speaker: VIOLA
line: What is the name?

speaker: Captain
line: Orsino.

speaker: VIOLA
line: Orsino! I have heard my father name him:

speaker: VIOLA
line: He was a bachelor then.

speaker: Captain
line: And so is now, or was so very late;

speaker: Captain
line: For but a month ago I went from hence,

speaker: Captain
line: And then 'twas fresh in murmur,--as, you know,

speaker: Captain
line: What great ones do the less will prattle of,--

speaker: Captain
line: That he did seek the love of fair Olivia.

speaker: VIOLA
line: What's she?

speaker: Captain
line: A virtuous maid, the daughter of a count

speaker: Captain
line: That died some twelvemonth since, then leaving her

speaker: Captain
line: In the protection of his son, her brother,

speaker: Captain
line: Who shortly also died: for whose dear love,

speaker: Captain
line: They say, she hath abjured the company

speaker: Captain
line: And sight of men.

speaker: VIOLA
line: O that I served that lady

speaker: VIOLA
line: And might not be delivered to the world,

speaker: VIOLA
line: Till I had made mine own occasion mellow,

speaker: VIOLA
line: What my estate is!

speaker: Captain
line: That were hard to compass;

speaker: Captain
line: Because she will admit no kind of suit,

speaker: Captain
line: No, not the duke's.

speaker: VIOLA
line: There is a fair behavior in thee, captain;

speaker: VIOLA
line: And though that nature with a beauteous wall

speaker: VIOLA
line: Doth oft close in pollution, yet of thee

speaker: VIOLA
line: I will believe thou hast a mind that suits

speaker: VIOLA
line: With this thy fair and outward character.

speaker: VIOLA
line: I prithee, and I'll pay thee bounteously,

speaker: VIOLA
line: Conceal me what I am, and be my aid

speaker: VIOLA
line: For such disguise as haply shall become

speaker: VIOLA
line: The form of my intent. I'll serve this duke:

speaker: VIOLA
line: Thou shall present me as an eunuch to him:

speaker: VIOLA
line: It may be worth thy pains; for I can sing

speaker: VIOLA
line: And speak to him in many sorts of music

speaker: VIOLA
line: That will allow me very worth his service.

speaker: VIOLA
line: What else may hap to time I will commit;

speaker: VIOLA
line: Only shape thou thy silence to my wit.

speaker: Captain
line: Be you his eunuch, and your mute I'll be:

speaker: Captain
line: When my tongue blabs, then let mine eyes not see.

speaker: VIOLA
line: I thank thee: lead me on.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: What a plague means my niece, to take the death of

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: her brother thus? I am sure care's an enemy to life.

speaker: MARIA
line: By my troth, Sir Toby, you must come in earlier o'

speaker: MARIA
line: nights: your cousin, my lady, takes great

speaker: MARIA
line: exceptions to your ill hours.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: Why, let her except, before excepted.

speaker: MARIA
line: Ay, but you must confine yourself within the modest

speaker: MARIA
line: limits of order.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: Confine! I'll confine myself no finer than I am:

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: these clothes are good enough to drink in; and so be

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: these boots too: an they be not, let them hang

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: themselves in their own straps.

speaker: MARIA
line: That quaffing and drinking will undo you: I heard

speaker: MARIA
line: my lady talk of it yesterday; and of a foolish

speaker: MARIA
line: knight that you brought in one night here to be her wooer.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: Who, Sir Andrew Aguecheek?

speaker: MARIA
line: Ay, he.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: He's as tall a man as any's in Illyria.

speaker: MARIA
line: What's that to the purpose?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: Why, he has three thousand ducats a year.

speaker: MARIA
line: Ay, but he'll have but a year in all these ducats:

speaker: MARIA
line: he's a very fool and a prodigal.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: Fie, that you'll say so! he plays o' the

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: viol-de-gamboys, and speaks three or four languages

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: word for word without book, and hath all the good

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: gifts of nature.

speaker: MARIA
line: He hath indeed, almost natural: for besides that

speaker: MARIA
line: he's a fool, he's a great quarreller: and but that

speaker: MARIA
line: he hath the gift of a coward to allay the gust he

speaker: MARIA
line: hath in quarrelling, 'tis thought among the prudent

speaker: MARIA
line: he would quickly have the gift of a grave.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: By this hand, they are scoundrels and subtractors

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: that say so of him. Who are they?

speaker: MARIA
line: They that add, moreover, he's drunk nightly in your company.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: With drinking healths to my niece: I'll drink to

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: her as long as there is a passage in my throat and

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: drink in Illyria: he's a coward and a coystrill

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: that will not drink to my niece till his brains turn

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: o' the toe like a parish-top. What, wench!

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: Castiliano vulgo! for here comes Sir Andrew Agueface.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: Sir Toby Belch! how now, Sir Toby Belch!

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: Sweet Sir Andrew!

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: Bless you, fair shrew.

speaker: MARIA
line: And you too, sir.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: Accost, Sir Andrew, accost.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: What's that?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: My niece's chambermaid.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: Good Mistress Accost, I desire better acquaintance.

speaker: MARIA
line: My name is Mary, sir.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: Good Mistress Mary Accost,--

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: You mistake, knight; 'accost' is front her, board

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: her, woo her, assail her.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: By my troth, I would not undertake her in this

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: company. Is that the meaning of 'accost'?

speaker: MARIA
line: Fare you well, gentlemen.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: An thou let part so, Sir Andrew, would thou mightst

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: never draw sword again.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: An you part so, mistress, I would I might never

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: draw sword again. Fair lady, do you think you have

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: fools in hand?

speaker: MARIA
line: Sir, I have not you by the hand.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: Marry, but you shall have; and here's my hand.

speaker: MARIA
line: Now, sir, 'thought is free:' I pray you, bring

speaker: MARIA
line: your hand to the buttery-bar and let it drink.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: Wherefore, sweet-heart? what's your metaphor?

speaker: MARIA
line: It's dry, sir.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: Why, I think so: I am not such an ass but I can

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: keep my hand dry. But what's your jest?

speaker: MARIA
line: A dry jest, sir.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: Are you full of them?

speaker: MARIA
line: Ay, sir, I have them at my fingers' ends: marry,

speaker: MARIA
line: now I let go your hand, I am barren.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: O knight thou lackest a cup of canary: when did I

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: see thee so put down?

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: Never in your life, I think; unless you see canary

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: put me down. Methinks sometimes I have no more wit

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: than a Christian or an ordinary man has: but I am a

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: great eater of beef and I believe that does harm to my wit.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: No question.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: An I thought that, I'ld forswear it. I'll ride home

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: to-morrow, Sir Toby.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: Pourquoi, my dear knight?

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: What is 'Pourquoi'? do or not do? I would I had

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: bestowed that time in the tongues that I have in

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: fencing, dancing and bear-baiting: O, had I but

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: followed the arts!

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: Then hadst thou had an excellent head of hair.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: Why, would that have mended my hair?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: Past question; for thou seest it will not curl by nature.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: But it becomes me well enough, does't not?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: Excellent; it hangs like flax on a distaff; and I

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: hope to see a housewife take thee between her legs

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: and spin it off.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: Faith, I'll home to-morrow, Sir Toby: your niece

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: will not be seen; or if she be, it's four to one

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: she'll none of me: the count himself here hard by woos her.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: She'll none o' the count: she'll not match above

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: her degree, neither in estate, years, nor wit; I

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: have heard her swear't. Tut, there's life in't,

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: man.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: I'll stay a month longer. I am a fellow o' the

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: strangest mind i' the world; I delight in masques

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: and revels sometimes altogether.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: Art thou good at these kickshawses, knight?

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: As any man in Illyria, whatsoever he be, under the

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: degree of my betters; and yet I will not compare

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: with an old man.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: What is thy excellence in a galliard, knight?

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: Faith, I can cut a caper.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: And I can cut the mutton to't.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: And I think I have the back-trick simply as strong

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: as any man in Illyria.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: Wherefore are these things hid? wherefore have

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: these gifts a curtain before 'em? are they like to

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: take dust, like Mistress Mall's picture? why dost

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: thou not go to church in a galliard and come home in

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: a coranto? My very walk should be a jig; I would not

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: so much as make water but in a sink-a-pace. What

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: dost thou mean? Is it a world to hide virtues in?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: I did think, by the excellent constitution of thy

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: leg, it was formed under the star of a galliard.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: Ay, 'tis strong, and it does indifferent well in a

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: flame-coloured stock. Shall we set about some revels?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: What shall we do else? were we not born under Taurus?

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: Taurus! That's sides and heart.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: No, sir; it is legs and thighs. Let me see the

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: caper; ha! higher: ha, ha! excellent!

speaker: VALENTINE
line: If the duke continue these favours towards you,

speaker: VALENTINE
line: Cesario, you are like to be much advanced: he hath

speaker: VALENTINE
line: known you but three days, and already you are no stranger.

speaker: VIOLA
line: You either fear his humour or my negligence, that

speaker: VIOLA
line: you call in question the continuance of his love:

speaker: VIOLA
line: is he inconstant, sir, in his favours?

speaker: VALENTINE
line: No, believe me.

speaker: VIOLA
line: I thank you. Here comes the count.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: Who saw Cesario, ho?

speaker: VIOLA
line: On your attendance, my lord; here.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: Stand you a while aloof, Cesario,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: Thou know'st no less but all; I have unclasp'd

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: To thee the book even of my secret soul:

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: Therefore, good youth, address thy gait unto her;

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: Be not denied access, stand at her doors,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: And tell them, there thy fixed foot shall grow

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: Till thou have audience.

speaker: VIOLA
line: Sure, my noble lord,

speaker: VIOLA
line: If she be so abandon'd to her sorrow

speaker: VIOLA
line: As it is spoke, she never will admit me.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: Be clamorous and leap all civil bounds

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: Rather than make unprofited return.

speaker: VIOLA
line: Say I do speak with her, my lord, what then?

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: O, then unfold the passion of my love,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: Surprise her with discourse of my dear faith:

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: It shall become thee well to act my woes;

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: She will attend it better in thy youth

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: Than in a nuncio's of more grave aspect.

speaker: VIOLA
line: I think not so, my lord.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: Dear lad, believe it;

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: For they shall yet belie thy happy years,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: That say thou art a man: Diana's lip

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: Is not more smooth and rubious; thy small pipe

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: Is as the maiden's organ, shrill and sound,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: And all is semblative a woman's part.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: I know thy constellation is right apt

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: For this affair. Some four or five attend him;

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: All, if you will; for I myself am best

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: When least in company. Prosper well in this,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: And thou shalt live as freely as thy lord,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: To call his fortunes thine.

speaker: VIOLA
line: I'll do my best

speaker: VIOLA
line: To woo your lady:

speaker: VIOLA
line: yet, a barful strife!

speaker: VIOLA
line: Whoe'er I woo, myself would be his wife.

speaker: MARIA
line: Nay, either tell me where thou hast been, or I will

speaker: MARIA
line: not open my lips so wide as a bristle may enter in

speaker: MARIA
line: way of thy excuse: my lady will hang thee for thy absence.

speaker: Clown
line: Let her hang me: he that is well hanged in this

speaker: Clown
line: world needs to fear no colours.

speaker: MARIA
line: Make that good.

speaker: Clown
line: He shall see none to fear.

speaker: MARIA
line: A good lenten answer: I can tell thee where that

speaker: MARIA
line: saying was born, of 'I fear no colours.'

speaker: Clown
line: Where, good Mistress Mary?

speaker: MARIA
line: In the wars; and that may you be bold to say in your foolery.

speaker: Clown
line: Well, God give them wisdom that have it; and those

speaker: Clown
line: that are fools, let them use their talents.

speaker: MARIA
line: Yet you will be hanged for being so long absent; or,

speaker: MARIA
line: to be turned away, is not that as good as a hanging to you?

speaker: Clown
line: Many a good hanging prevents a bad marriage; and,

speaker: Clown
line: for turning away, let summer bear it out.

speaker: MARIA
line: You are resolute, then?

speaker: Clown
line: Not so, neither; but I am resolved on two points.

speaker: MARIA
line: That if one break, the other will hold; or, if both

speaker: MARIA
line: break, your gaskins fall.

speaker: Clown
line: Apt, in good faith; very apt. Well, go thy way; if

speaker: Clown
line: Sir Toby would leave drinking, thou wert as witty a

speaker: Clown
line: piece of Eve's flesh as any in Illyria.

speaker: MARIA
line: Peace, you rogue, no more o' that. Here comes my

speaker: MARIA
line: lady: make your excuse wisely, you were best.

speaker: Clown
line: Wit, an't be thy will, put me into good fooling!

speaker: Clown
line: Those wits, that think they have thee, do very oft

speaker: Clown
line: prove fools; and I, that am sure I lack thee, may

speaker: Clown
line: pass for a wise man: for what says Quinapalus?

speaker: Clown
line: 'Better a witty fool, than a foolish wit.'

speaker: Clown
line: God bless thee, lady!

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Take the fool away.

speaker: Clown
line: Do you not hear, fellows? Take away the lady.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Go to, you're a dry fool; I'll no more of you:

speaker: OLIVIA
line: besides, you grow dishonest.

speaker: Clown
line: Two faults, madonna, that drink and good counsel

speaker: Clown
line: will amend: for give the dry fool drink, then is

speaker: Clown
line: the fool not dry: bid the dishonest man mend

speaker: Clown
line: himself; if he mend, he is no longer dishonest; if

speaker: Clown
line: he cannot, let the botcher mend him. Any thing

speaker: Clown
line: that's mended is but patched: virtue that

speaker: Clown
line: transgresses is but patched with sin; and sin that

speaker: Clown
line: amends is but patched with virtue. If that this

speaker: Clown
line: simple syllogism will serve, so; if it will not,

speaker: Clown
line: what remedy? As there is no true cuckold but

speaker: Clown
line: calamity, so beauty's a flower. The lady bade take

speaker: Clown
line: away the fool; therefore, I say again, take her away.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Sir, I bade them take away you.

speaker: Clown
line: Misprision in the highest degree! Lady, cucullus non

speaker: Clown
line: facit monachum; that's as much to say as I wear not

speaker: Clown
line: motley in my brain. Good madonna, give me leave to

speaker: Clown
line: prove you a fool.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Can you do it?

speaker: Clown
line: Dexterously, good madonna.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Make your proof.

speaker: Clown
line: I must catechise you for it, madonna: good my mouse

speaker: Clown
line: of virtue, answer me.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Well, sir, for want of other idleness, I'll bide your proof.

speaker: Clown
line: Good madonna, why mournest thou?

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Good fool, for my brother's death.

speaker: Clown
line: I think his soul is in hell, madonna.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: I know his soul is in heaven, fool.

speaker: Clown
line: The more fool, madonna, to mourn for your brother's

speaker: Clown
line: soul being in heaven. Take away the fool, gentlemen.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: What think you of this fool, Malvolio? doth he not mend?

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: Yes, and shall do till the pangs of death shake him:

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: infirmity, that decays the wise, doth ever make the

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: better fool.

speaker: Clown
line: God send you, sir, a speedy infirmity, for the

speaker: Clown
line: better increasing your folly! Sir Toby will be

speaker: Clown
line: sworn that I am no fox; but he will not pass his

speaker: Clown
line: word for two pence that you are no fool.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: How say you to that, Malvolio?

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: I marvel your ladyship takes delight in such a

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: barren rascal: I saw him put down the other day

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: with an ordinary fool that has no more brain

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: than a stone. Look you now, he's out of his guard

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: already; unless you laugh and minister occasion to

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: him, he is gagged. I protest, I take these wise men,

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: that crow so at these set kind of fools, no better

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: than the fools' zanies.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Oh, you are sick of self-love, Malvolio, and taste

speaker: OLIVIA
line: with a distempered appetite. To be generous,

speaker: OLIVIA
line: guiltless and of free disposition, is to take those

speaker: OLIVIA
line: things for bird-bolts that you deem cannon-bullets:

speaker: OLIVIA
line: there is no slander in an allowed fool, though he do

speaker: OLIVIA
line: nothing but rail; nor no railing in a known discreet

speaker: OLIVIA
line: man, though he do nothing but reprove.

speaker: Clown
line: Now Mercury endue thee with leasing, for thou

speaker: Clown
line: speakest well of fools!

speaker: MARIA
line: Madam, there is at the gate a young gentleman much

speaker: MARIA
line: desires to speak with you.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: From the Count Orsino, is it?

speaker: MARIA
line: I know not, madam: 'tis a fair young man, and well attended.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Who of my people hold him in delay?

speaker: MARIA
line: Sir Toby, madam, your kinsman.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Fetch him off, I pray you; he speaks nothing but

speaker: OLIVIA
line: madman: fie on him!

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Go you, Malvolio: if it be a suit from the count, I

speaker: OLIVIA
line: am sick, or not at home; what you will, to dismiss it.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Now you see, sir, how your fooling grows old, and

speaker: OLIVIA
line: people dislike it.

speaker: Clown
line: Thou hast spoke for us, madonna, as if thy eldest

speaker: Clown
line: son should be a fool; whose skull Jove cram with

speaker: Clown
line: brains! for,--here he comes,--one of thy kin has a

speaker: Clown
line: most weak pia mater.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: By mine honour, half drunk. What is he at the gate, cousin?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: A gentleman.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: A gentleman! what gentleman?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: 'Tis a gentle man here--a plague o' these

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: pickle-herring! How now, sot!

speaker: Clown
line: Good Sir Toby!

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Cousin, cousin, how have you come so early by this lethargy?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: Lechery! I defy lechery. There's one at the gate.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Ay, marry, what is he?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: Let him be the devil, an he will, I care not: give

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: me faith, say I. Well, it's all one.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: What's a drunken man like, fool?

speaker: Clown
line: Like a drowned man, a fool and a mad man: one

speaker: Clown
line: draught above heat makes him a fool; the second mads

speaker: Clown
line: him; and a third drowns him.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Go thou and seek the crowner, and let him sit o' my

speaker: OLIVIA
line: coz; for he's in the third degree of drink, he's

speaker: OLIVIA
line: drowned: go, look after him.

speaker: Clown
line: He is but mad yet, madonna; and the fool shall look

speaker: Clown
line: to the madman.

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: Madam, yond young fellow swears he will speak with

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: you. I told him you were sick; he takes on him to

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: understand so much, and therefore comes to speak

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: with you. I told him you were asleep; he seems to

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: have a foreknowledge of that too, and therefore

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: comes to speak with you. What is to be said to him,

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: lady? he's fortified against any denial.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Tell him he shall not speak with me.

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: Has been told so; and he says, he'll stand at your

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: door like a sheriff's post, and be the supporter to

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: a bench, but he'll speak with you.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: What kind o' man is he?

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: Why, of mankind.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: What manner of man?

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: Of very ill manner; he'll speak with you, will you or no.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Of what personage and years is he?

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: Not yet old enough for a man, nor young enough for

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: a boy; as a squash is before 'tis a peascod, or a

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: cooling when 'tis almost an apple: 'tis with him

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: in standing water, between boy and man. He is very

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: well-favoured and he speaks very shrewishly; one

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: would think his mother's milk were scarce out of him.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Let him approach: call in my gentlewoman.

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: Gentlewoman, my lady calls.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Give me my veil: come, throw it o'er my face.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: We'll once more hear Orsino's embassy.

speaker: VIOLA
line: The honourable lady of the house, which is she?

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Speak to me; I shall answer for her.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Your will?

speaker: VIOLA
line: Most radiant, exquisite and unmatchable beauty,--I

speaker: VIOLA
line: pray you, tell me if this be the lady of the house,

speaker: VIOLA
line: for I never saw her: I would be loath to cast away

speaker: VIOLA
line: my speech, for besides that it is excellently well

speaker: VIOLA
line: penned, I have taken great pains to con it. Good

speaker: VIOLA
line: beauties, let me sustain no scorn; I am very

speaker: VIOLA
line: comptible, even to the least sinister usage.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Whence came you, sir?

speaker: VIOLA
line: I can say little more than I have studied, and that

speaker: VIOLA
line: question's out of my part. Good gentle one, give me

speaker: VIOLA
line: modest assurance if you be the lady of the house,

speaker: VIOLA
line: that I may proceed in my speech.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Are you a comedian?

speaker: VIOLA
line: No, my profound heart: and yet, by the very fangs

speaker: VIOLA
line: of malice I swear, I am not that I play. Are you

speaker: VIOLA
line: the lady of the house?

speaker: OLIVIA
line: If I do not usurp myself, I am.

speaker: VIOLA
line: Most certain, if you are she, you do usurp

speaker: VIOLA
line: yourself; for what is yours to bestow is not yours

speaker: VIOLA
line: to reserve. But this is from my commission: I will

speaker: VIOLA
line: on with my speech in your praise, and then show you

speaker: VIOLA
line: the heart of my message.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Come to what is important in't: I forgive you the praise.

speaker: VIOLA
line: Alas, I took great pains to study it, and 'tis poetical.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: It is the more like to be feigned: I pray you,

speaker: OLIVIA
line: keep it in. I heard you were saucy at my gates,

speaker: OLIVIA
line: and allowed your approach rather to wonder at you

speaker: OLIVIA
line: than to hear you. If you be not mad, be gone; if

speaker: OLIVIA
line: you have reason, be brief: 'tis not that time of

speaker: OLIVIA
line: moon with me to make one in so skipping a dialogue.

speaker: MARIA
line: Will you hoist sail, sir? here lies your way.

speaker: VIOLA
line: No, good swabber; I am to hull here a little

speaker: VIOLA
line: longer. Some mollification for your giant, sweet

speaker: VIOLA
line: lady. Tell me your mind: I am a messenger.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Sure, you have some hideous matter to deliver, when

speaker: OLIVIA
line: the courtesy of it is so fearful. Speak your office.

speaker: VIOLA
line: It alone concerns your ear. I bring no overture of

speaker: VIOLA
line: war, no taxation of homage: I hold the olive in my

speaker: VIOLA
line: hand; my words are as fun of peace as matter.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Yet you began rudely. What are you? what would you?

speaker: VIOLA
line: The rudeness that hath appeared in me have I

speaker: VIOLA
line: learned from my entertainment. What I am, and what I

speaker: VIOLA
line: would, are as secret as maidenhead; to your ears,

speaker: VIOLA
line: divinity, to any other's, profanation.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Give us the place alone: we will hear this divinity.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Now, sir, what is your text?

speaker: VIOLA
line: Most sweet lady,--

speaker: OLIVIA
line: A comfortable doctrine, and much may be said of it.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Where lies your text?

speaker: VIOLA
line: In Orsino's bosom.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: In his bosom! In what chapter of his bosom?

speaker: VIOLA
line: To answer by the method, in the first of his heart.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: O, I have read it: it is heresy. Have you no more to say?

speaker: VIOLA
line: Good madam, let me see your face.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Have you any commission from your lord to negotiate

speaker: OLIVIA
line: with my face? You are now out of your text: but

speaker: OLIVIA
line: we will draw the curtain and show you the picture.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Look you, sir, such a one I was this present: is't

speaker: OLIVIA
line: not well done?

speaker: VIOLA
line: Excellently done, if God did all.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: 'Tis in grain, sir; 'twill endure wind and weather.

speaker: VIOLA
line: 'Tis beauty truly blent, whose red and white

speaker: VIOLA
line: Nature's own sweet and cunning hand laid on:

speaker: VIOLA
line: Lady, you are the cruell'st she alive,

speaker: VIOLA
line: If you will lead these graces to the grave

speaker: VIOLA
line: And leave the world no copy.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: O, sir, I will not be so hard-hearted; I will give

speaker: OLIVIA
line: out divers schedules of my beauty: it shall be

speaker: OLIVIA
line: inventoried, and every particle and utensil

speaker: OLIVIA
line: labelled to my will: as, item, two lips,

speaker: OLIVIA
line: indifferent red; item, two grey eyes, with lids to

speaker: OLIVIA
line: them; item, one neck, one chin, and so forth. Were

speaker: OLIVIA
line: you sent hither to praise me?

speaker: VIOLA
line: I see you what you are, you are too proud;

speaker: VIOLA
line: But, if you were the devil, you are fair.

speaker: VIOLA
line: My lord and master loves you: O, such love

speaker: VIOLA
line: Could be but recompensed, though you were crown'd

speaker: VIOLA
line: The nonpareil of beauty!

speaker: OLIVIA
line: How does he love me?

speaker: VIOLA
line: With adorations, fertile tears,

speaker: VIOLA
line: With groans that thunder love, with sighs of fire.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Your lord does know my mind; I cannot love him:

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Yet I suppose him virtuous, know him noble,

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Of great estate, of fresh and stainless youth;

speaker: OLIVIA
line: In voices well divulged, free, learn'd and valiant;

speaker: OLIVIA
line: And in dimension and the shape of nature

speaker: OLIVIA
line: A gracious person: but yet I cannot love him;

speaker: OLIVIA
line: He might have took his answer long ago.

speaker: VIOLA
line: If I did love you in my master's flame,

speaker: VIOLA
line: With such a suffering, such a deadly life,

speaker: VIOLA
line: In your denial I would find no sense;

speaker: VIOLA
line: I would not understand it.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Why, what would you?

speaker: VIOLA
line: Make me a willow cabin at your gate,

speaker: VIOLA
line: And call upon my soul within the house;

speaker: VIOLA
line: Write loyal cantons of contemned love

speaker: VIOLA
line: And sing them loud even in the dead of night;

speaker: VIOLA
line: Halloo your name to the reverberate hills

speaker: VIOLA
line: And make the babbling gossip of the air

speaker: VIOLA
line: Cry out 'Olivia!' O, You should not rest

speaker: VIOLA
line: Between the elements of air and earth,

speaker: VIOLA
line: But you should pity me!

speaker: OLIVIA
line: You might do much.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: What is your parentage?

speaker: VIOLA
line: Above my fortunes, yet my state is well:

speaker: VIOLA
line: I am a gentleman.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Get you to your lord;

speaker: OLIVIA
line: I cannot love him: let him send no more;

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Unless, perchance, you come to me again,

speaker: OLIVIA
line: To tell me how he takes it. Fare you well:

speaker: OLIVIA
line: I thank you for your pains: spend this for me.

speaker: VIOLA
line: I am no fee'd post, lady; keep your purse:

speaker: VIOLA
line: My master, not myself, lacks recompense.

speaker: VIOLA
line: Love make his heart of flint that you shall love;

speaker: VIOLA
line: And let your fervor, like my master's, be

speaker: VIOLA
line: Placed in contempt! Farewell, fair cruelty.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: 'What is your parentage?'

speaker: OLIVIA
line: 'Above my fortunes, yet my state is well:

speaker: OLIVIA
line: I am a gentleman.' I'll be sworn thou art;

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Thy tongue, thy face, thy limbs, actions and spirit,

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Do give thee five-fold blazon: not too fast:

speaker: OLIVIA
line: soft, soft!

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Unless the master were the man. How now!

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Even so quickly may one catch the plague?

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Methinks I feel this youth's perfections

speaker: OLIVIA
line: With an invisible and subtle stealth

speaker: OLIVIA
line: To creep in at mine eyes. Well, let it be.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: What ho, Malvolio!

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: Here, madam, at your service.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Run after that same peevish messenger,

speaker: OLIVIA
line: The county's man: he left this ring behind him,

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Would I or not: tell him I'll none of it.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Desire him not to flatter with his lord,

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Nor hold him up with hopes; I am not for him:

speaker: OLIVIA
line: If that the youth will come this way to-morrow,

speaker: OLIVIA
line: I'll give him reasons for't: hie thee, Malvolio.

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: Madam, I will.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: I do I know not what, and fear to find

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Mine eye too great a flatterer for my mind.

speaker: OLIVIA
line: Fate, show thy force: ourselves we do not owe;

speaker: OLIVIA
line: What is decreed must be, and be this so.

speaker: ANTONIO
line: Will you stay no longer? nor will you not that I go with you?

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: By your patience, no. My stars shine darkly over

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: me: the malignancy of my fate might perhaps

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: distemper yours; therefore I shall crave of you your

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: leave that I may bear my evils alone: it were a bad

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: recompense for your love, to lay any of them on you.

speaker: ANTONIO
line: Let me yet know of you whither you are bound.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: No, sooth, sir: my determinate voyage is mere

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: extravagancy. But I perceive in you so excellent a

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: touch of modesty, that you will not extort from me

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: what I am willing to keep in; therefore it charges

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: me in manners the rather to express myself. You

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: must know of me then, Antonio, my name is Sebastian,

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: which I called Roderigo. My father was that

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: Sebastian of Messaline, whom I know you have heard

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: of. He left behind him myself and a sister, both

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: born in an hour: if the heavens had been pleased,

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: would we had so ended! but you, sir, altered that;

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: for some hour before you took me from the breach of

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: the sea was my sister drowned.

speaker: ANTONIO
line: Alas the day!

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: A lady, sir, though it was said she much resembled

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: me, was yet of many accounted beautiful: but,

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: though I could not with such estimable wonder

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: overfar believe that, yet thus far I will boldly

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: publish her; she bore a mind that envy could not but

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: call fair. She is drowned already, sir, with salt

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: water, though I seem to drown her remembrance again with more.

speaker: ANTONIO
line: Pardon me, sir, your bad entertainment.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: O good Antonio, forgive me your trouble.

speaker: ANTONIO
line: If you will not murder me for my love, let me be

speaker: ANTONIO
line: your servant.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: If you will not undo what you have done, that is,

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: kill him whom you have recovered, desire it not.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: Fare ye well at once: my bosom is full of kindness,

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: and I am yet so near the manners of my mother, that

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: upon the least occasion more mine eyes will tell

speaker: SEBASTIAN
line: tales of me. I am bound to the Count Orsino's court: farewell.

speaker: ANTONIO
line: The gentleness of all the gods go with thee!

speaker: ANTONIO
line: I have many enemies in Orsino's court,

speaker: ANTONIO
line: Else would I very shortly see thee there.

speaker: ANTONIO
line: But, come what may, I do adore thee so,

speaker: ANTONIO
line: That danger shall seem sport, and I will go.

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: Were not you even now with the Countess Olivia?

speaker: VIOLA
line: Even now, sir; on a moderate pace I have since

speaker: VIOLA
line: arrived but hither.

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: She returns this ring to you, sir: you might have

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: saved me my pains, to have taken it away yourself.

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: She adds, moreover, that you should put your lord

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: into a desperate assurance she will none of him:

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: and one thing more, that you be never so hardy to

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: come again in his affairs, unless it be to report

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: your lord's taking of this. Receive it so.

speaker: VIOLA
line: She took the ring of me: I'll none of it.

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: Come, sir, you peevishly threw it to her; and her

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: will is, it should be so returned: if it be worth

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: stooping for, there it lies in your eye; if not, be

speaker: MALVOLIO
line: it his that finds it.

speaker: VIOLA
line: I left no ring with her: what means this lady?

speaker: VIOLA
line: Fortune forbid my outside have not charm'd her!

speaker: VIOLA
line: She made good view of me; indeed, so much,

speaker: VIOLA
line: That sure methought her eyes had lost her tongue,

speaker: VIOLA
line: For she did speak in starts distractedly.

speaker: VIOLA
line: She loves me, sure; the cunning of her passion

speaker: VIOLA
line: Invites me in this churlish messenger.

speaker: VIOLA
line: None of my lord's ring! why, he sent her none.

speaker: VIOLA
line: I am the man: if it be so, as 'tis,

speaker: VIOLA
line: Poor lady, she were better love a dream.

speaker: VIOLA
line: Disguise, I see, thou art a wickedness,

speaker: VIOLA
line: Wherein the pregnant enemy does much.

speaker: VIOLA
line: How easy is it for the proper-false

speaker: VIOLA
line: In women's waxen hearts to set their forms!

speaker: VIOLA
line: Alas, our frailty is the cause, not we!

speaker: VIOLA
line: For such as we are made of, such we be.

speaker: VIOLA
line: How will this fadge? my master loves her dearly;

speaker: VIOLA
line: And I, poor monster, fond as much on him;

speaker: VIOLA
line: And she, mistaken, seems to dote on me.

speaker: VIOLA
line: What will become of this? As I am man,

speaker: VIOLA
line: My state is desperate for my master's love;

speaker: VIOLA
line: As I am woman,--now alas the day!--

speaker: VIOLA
line: What thriftless sighs shall poor Olivia breathe!

speaker: VIOLA
line: O time! thou must untangle this, not I;

speaker: VIOLA
line: It is too hard a knot for me to untie!

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: Approach, Sir Andrew: not to be abed after

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: midnight is to be up betimes; and 'diluculo

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: surgere,' thou know'st,--

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: Nay, my troth, I know not: but I know, to be up

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: late is to be up late.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: A false conclusion: I hate it as an unfilled can.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: To be up after midnight and to go to bed then, is

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: early: so that to go to bed after midnight is to go

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: to bed betimes. Does not our life consist of the

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: four elements?

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: Faith, so they say; but I think it rather consists

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: of eating and drinking.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: Thou'rt a scholar; let us therefore eat and drink.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: Marian, I say! a stoup of wine!

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: Here comes the fool, i' faith.

speaker: Clown
line: How now, my hearts! did you never see the picture

speaker: Clown
line: of 'we three'?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: Welcome, ass. Now let's have a catch.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: By my troth, the fool has an excellent breast. I

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: had rather than forty shillings I had such a leg,

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: and so sweet a breath to sing, as the fool has. In

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: sooth, thou wast in very gracious fooling last

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: night, when thou spokest of Pigrogromitus, of the

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: Vapians passing the equinoctial of Queubus: 'twas

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: very good, i' faith. I sent thee sixpence for thy

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: leman: hadst it?

speaker: Clown
line: I did impeticos thy gratillity; for Malvolio's nose

speaker: Clown
line: is no whipstock: my lady has a white hand, and the

speaker: Clown
line: Myrmidons are no bottle-ale houses.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: Excellent! why, this is the best fooling, when all

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: is done. Now, a song.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: Come on; there is sixpence for you: let's have a song.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: There's a testril of me too: if one knight give a--

speaker: Clown
line: Would you have a love-song, or a song of good life?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
line: A love-song, a love-song.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
line: Ay, ay: I care not for good life.

speaker: Clown
line: Sings

speaker: Clown
line: O mistress mine, where are you roaming?

speaker: Clown

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: We will not part from hence. Cesario, come;

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: For so you shall be, while you are a man;

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: But when in other habits you are seen,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
line: Orsino's mistress and his fancy's queen.

speaker: Clown
line: Sings

speaker: Clown
line: When that I was and a little tiny boy,

speaker: Clown
line: With hey, ho, the wind and the rain,

speaker: Clown
line: A foolish thing was but a toy,

speaker: Clown
line: For the rain it raineth every day.

speaker: Clown
line: But when I came to man's estate,

speaker: Clown
line: With hey, ho, &c.

speaker: Clown
line: 'Gainst knaves and thieves men shut their gate,

speaker: Clown
line: For the rain, &c.

speaker: Clown
line: But when I came, alas! to wive,

speaker: Clown
line: With hey, ho, &c.

speaker: Clown
line: By swaggering could I never thrive,

speaker: Clown
line: For the rain, &c.

speaker: Clown
line: But when I came unto my beds,

speaker: Clown
line: With hey, ho, &c.

speaker: Clown
line: With toss-pots still had drunken heads,

speaker: Clown
line: For the rain, &c.

speaker: Clown
line: A great while ago the world begun,

speaker: Clown
line: With hey, ho, &c.

speaker: Clown
line: But that's all one, our play is done,

speaker: Clown
line: And we'll strive to please you every day.
